data.title: Erdos problem #728 was solved more or less autonomously by AI
data.summary: Terence Tao has shared that Erdős Problem #728 has been solved more or less autonomously by AI. This represents a significant milestone in the application of artificial intelligence to mathematical problem-solving. The post discusses how AI systems can contribute to solving classic Erdős problems—a collection of famous open problems in mathematics. This achievement highlights the growing capability of machine learning systems to tackle complex mathematical challenges that have remained open for decades. The solution demonstrates how AI can analyze mathematical patterns, explore solution spaces exhaustively, and assist in proof construction and verification.
actions: Located rank 1 post on HN listing

data.title: JavaScript Demos in 140 Characters
data.summary: A popular Hacker News post featuring JavaScript demonstrations created using Dwitter.net, a platform dedicated to showcasing tiny JavaScript programs limited to 140 characters. The post generated significant community interest with 181 points and 40 comments, highlighting the creative potential of JavaScript when developers are constrained by strict character limits. The demonstrations showcase stunning visual animations and generative art created with minimal code, appealing to developers interested in code golf, creative coding, and JavaScript capabilities.

data.title: RTX 5090 and Raspberry Pi: Can it game?
data.summary: Scott's blog post explores an ambitious experiment connecting an NVIDIA RTX 5090 graphics card to a Raspberry Pi to test gaming performance on ARM-based systems. The post documents the hardware setup, technical challenges with ARM GPU driver compatibility, and community-provided solutions. The author successfully demonstrates GPU acceleration on ARM single-board computers, overcoming memory alignment and DMA coherence issues through driver patches. Key findings show that while unconventional, high-end GPU gaming is achievable on budget Raspberry Pi platforms, representing an important proof of concept for GPU computing on ARM architectures.
